title: PCT 23: In the days of the small-pox
author: Mrs. Coming-Day, nakwêsis

sentences.english: This story took place at the time of the smallpox.

sentences.original: êkwah kîtahtawê nâ kisêyiniw âhkosiw, itah êh-kapêsicik.
sentences.text: êkwa kîtahtawê nâ kisêyiniw âhkosiw ita ê-kapêsicik
sentences.english: A certain old man took sick where they were encamped.
He was driving his team, for they were on the trek.

sentences.original: êkwah itah êh-kapêsicik, êkotah mistahi âhkosiw kisêyiniw anah.
sentences.text: êkwa ita ê-kapêsicik êkota mistahi âhkosiw kisêyiniw ana
sentences.english: And then, there where they camped, that old man became very sick.

sentences.original: omis îsiyîhkâsôw awa kisêyiniw : pitikwayasit isiyîhkâsôw.
sentences.text: ômisi isiyîhkâsôw awa kisêyiniw pitikwayasit isiyîhkâsôw
sentences.english: This was the old man's name: Club-Foot was his name.
He was the one who fell very sick.

sentences.original: êkwah nêwâw êh-tipiskâk, êkwah pimisin; wîh-nipiw.
sentences.text: êkwa nêwâw ê-tipiskâk êkwa pimisin wî-nipiw
sentences.english: For four nights he lay there; he was at the point of death.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah piciwak ôki kotakak ayîsiyiniwak;
sentences.text: êkwa êkota piciwak ôki kotakak ayîsiyiniwak
sentences.english: Then the other people there moved camp;
as was to be expected, that family was abandoned there.

sentences.original: pêyak nôtokêsiw êkwah oskinîkiskwêw pêyak; êwakô êkâ kâ-wâpit aw oskinîkiskwêw; mistahi kitimâkisiw.
sentences.text: pêyak nôtokêsiw êkwa oskinîkiskwêw pêyak êwako êkâ kâ-wâpit awa oskinîkiskwêw mistahi kitimâkisiw
sentences.english: An old woman and a young woman;  and this young woman was blind; she was pitiable indeed.
They were not able to arrange their house.

sentences.original: êh-nipit êkotah wîkimêwak; êkotah awa kisêyiniw pimisin.
sentences.text: ê-nipit êkota wîkimêwak êkota awa kisêyiniw pimisin
sentences.english: When the old man died, they stayed there with him; there lay the old man.
For two nights they stayed with him.
Then the old woman took sick.
For two nights she barely lived.

sentences.original: âsay kêkâc êh-wâpahk, namoya pimâtisiw; nipiw awa nôtokêsiw.
sentences.text: âsay kêkâc ê-wâpahk namôya pimâtisiw nipiw awa nôtokêsiw
sentences.english: When it was almost dawn, she was no longer alive; the old woman had died.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah pêyakôw êkâh kâ-wâpit oskinîkiskwêw, okâwiyah kâ-nipiyit.
sentences.text: êkwa êkota pêyakôw êkâ kâ-wâpit oskinîkiskwêw okâwiya kâ-nipiyit
sentences.english: Then that blind young woman was alone there, she whose mother had died.

sentences.original: êkwah êkotah, tânisi nika-tôtên ? êkosi itêyihtam;
sentences.english: Then, “What shall I do?” she thought;
“I shall not go away from here;
I too shall die in this place,” she thought.
So she stayed there.
“In any case I too shall die.”

sentences.original: êkwah okâwiyah ôhi kîtahtawê, hâw, ntânis, sipwêhtê; niyah!
sentences.english: Then suddenly her mother said to her, “Now, my daughter, depart from here; go!
Depart even now!” she said to her, speaking as the spirit of one departed to one still alive,
“Go, leave!”

sentences.original: misatimwak nisto âh-ayâwêw, pêyak mistacimosis; nêô.
sentences.text: misatimwak nisto âh-ayâwêw pêyak mistacimosis nêwo
sentences.english: She had three horses and one foal; four.
“Very well, I shall depart,” she answered.
“But where, I wonder, is the road?
I am blind;
I do not know,”
So then she made ready.
The horses came to where she was.
Then she took hold of those horses.
She hitched them up; she took a saddle and harnessed them.
Then she wept.
She went out of the tent.

sentences.original: êkwah apisîs iwahikanisah êkotah aspapiwinihk tahkopitêw. apisîs pimîs.
sentences.text: êkwa apisîs îwahikanisa êkota aspapiwinihk tahkopitêw apisîs pimîs
sentences.english: A little chopped meat she tied there to the saddle, and a bit of fat.
She took her father's tobacco-pouch; she put it into her garment.

sentences.original: maskihkîwâpoy otinam, mîn âskihkosah, wiyâkanis. êkwah kâ-sipwêhtêt.
sentences.text: maskihkîwâpoy otinam mîna askihkosa wiyâkanis êkwa kâ-sipwêhtêt
sentences.english: She took some tea, and a small kettle, and a cup, and set out.
She wept.
“I wonder how I shall keep alive”, she thought;
“I am blind.”
She set out; she led the horses on the lines.
She sought the road.

sentences.original: êkwah ositah ohci mêskanaw êh-ntonahk, piyisk miskam mêskanaw.
sentences.text: êkwa osita ohci mêskanaw ê-nitonahk piyisk miskam mêskanaw
sentences.english: Seeking the road with her feet, at last she found it.
Then she set out.
She wept as she walked on.
“No doubt I shall die,” she thought.
She walked a long ways.
“Now I shall ride.”
So then she mounted a horse.
The horses set out; they trotted on.
On the first day the horses trotted quite a long time.
At last she knew that night was at hand.
She knew that there was a grove of trees: “Here is the road, here the grove.”
She went into the wood; there she camped.
She did not sleep.

sentences.original: êh-wâpahk êkwah sipwêhtêw; ntonam mîna mêskanaw.
sentences.text: ê-wâpahk êkwa sipwêhtêw nitonam mîna mêskanaw
sentences.english: At daybreak she set out again; again she sought the road.
Like this, with her feet, she sought the road.
She found the road.
Again she mounted.
She set out on the road; the horses trotted along.

sentences.original: nama kêkway nipiy ôtah ayâw; nôhtêyâpâkwêw.
sentences.text: nama kêkway nipiy ôta ayâw nôhtêyâpâkwêw
sentences.english: She had no water; she was thirsty.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê - misatimwah, pimipahtâwak misatimwak ,- nipiy miskam.
sentences.text: kîtahtawê misatimwa pimipahtâwak misatimwak nipiy miskam
sentences.english: Presently - the horses were trotting along, - she found some water.

sentences.original: minihkwêwak êkwah êkotah misatimwak min âna îskwêw.
sentences.text: minihkwêwak êkwa êkota misatimwak mîna ana iskwêw
sentences.english: Then the horses and that woman drank there.
Then she mounted again;
the horses found the road.
The horses trotted along.
When night fell she slept; she camped again.
Suddenly the horses went, “Brrr!”
They wanted to run away.
She grew frightened.
She had tied them up.
She took them; she mounted one.
She fled.
The road was not there.
“This isn't the road;
where can the road be?”
Then again when night fell, she camped.
There she slept;
there was some water, a lake.
At daybreak she went from there.
“And whither now?”
By this time she had nothing to eat.
She had eaten all her food.
She went on, riding.
“Whither, I wonder,” she thought.

sentences.original: mêkwâc êh-pimohtêt, kîtahtawê nipiy pahkopêwak ôki misatimwak.
sentences.text: mêkwâc ê-pimohtêt kîtahtawê nipiy pahkopêwak ôki misatimwak
sentences.english: As she went along, presently the horses were going into water.
At last it came as high as this.
She turned back.
She set out again.
She thought it a long ways.

sentences.original: oma êh-sipwêhtêt, omah ispatinâw kiskêyihtam, êh-âmaciwêt, mistah êh-spatinâyik.
sentences.text: ôma ê-sipwêhtêt ôma ispatinâw kiskêyihtam ê-âmaciwêt mistahi ê-ispatinâyik
sentences.english: Here when she set out, she knew that it was a hill, that she was going up a high hill.
She rode there.
On top of the hill in a place, she dismounted.
She wept.
Then she was sitting there.
Presently the horses grew frightened; “Brrr!”
They made to run away.
She sat there.
“Perhaps the Blackfoot will strike me down; they will kill me,” she thought.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê ayîsiyiniwah, wâhwâ! itik; kikitimâkisin, itik.
sentences.english: Presently some people said to her, “Dear me! You are in a sorry state.”
Someone kissed her.
The woman wept.
“There, your life is saved,” they told her, for some Cree had found her.

sentences.original: mistahi pakwâtam ana nâpêw ê-kitimâkisiyit ôhi iskwêwah.
sentences.text: mistahi pakwâtam ana nâpêw ê-kitimâkisiyit ôhi iskwêwa
sentences.english: That man was greatly disturbed at the woman's plight.

sentences.original: êkos îsi otihtahêw kisiwâk mîkiwâhpah, êh-kîwêhtahât.
sentences.text: êkosi isi otihtahêw kisiwâk mîkiwâhpa ê-kîwêhtahât
sentences.english: So he took her to some tents that were close by, he took her home with him.
He arrived at the camp.
That man was very well off.
“I haven't any tobacco,” he said to her.

sentences.original: ow îskwêw otinêw cistêmâwah; miyêw ôhi nâpêwah ôhi, maskihkîwâpoy mînah.
sentences.text: awa iskwêw otinêw cistêmâwa miyêw ôhi nâpêwa ôhi maskihkîwâpoy mîna
sentences.english: The woman took the tobacco; she gave it to that man, and the tea as well.

sentences.original: êkotah, mistahi kitatamihin, itwêw awa nâpêw êh-miyiht cistêmâwah.
sentences.text: êkota itwêw awa nâpêw ê-miyiht cistêmâwa
sentences.english: Then, “You are doing me a great kindness,” said the man when he was given the tobacco.
And there that woman was able to live.
So that is the end of this tale.

sentences.original: niki-wâpamâw ana yskwêw; mina nâpêw ana ninisitawêyimâw kâ-kîh-miskawât.
sentences.text: nikî-wâpamâw ana iskwêw mîna nâpêw ana ninisitawêyimâw kâ-kî-miskawât
sentences.english: I saw that woman; and I knew the man who found her.
